title: Paragon Oil font? (1930's/1940's)
content: Any idea what the main font is on this one? ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130312074044im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/21301.jpg)
author: anonymous

comments.content: Asparagirl, Mark is the man for this assignment. You can see his work in Indie Fonts 2 and Grant I agree with you the lower case g is stunning.
[Here's another example](%22http://www.frankjump.com/039.html%22) in a slightly different style.
Mark do you like that g too
Me too - it reminds me a little of the lc g in Miguel's [Fundamental](http://web.archive.org/web/20130312074044/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/29/1031.html).

If it helps any, the logo was probably designed in New York City (the company was based in Brooklyn, then Long Island). I'm less certain about the timeline, but I would think (from company history, not from the font itself) that it was possibly designed in the mid-1930's?   
   
Thanks in advance. :-)
Oh, well. Anybody wanna turn that into a font for me? :-)
I would be surprised if that was a font. Especially if it's as old as as you say, it's likely to have been done by hand.
